video.title: Tales of the Shire: A The Lord of The Rings™ Game | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Yes, you read that title correctly. The official 
name of this game is &quot;Tales of the Shire:

A The Lord of the Rings (TM) Game. Not &quot;A Lord of 
the Rings game.&quot; God, no. How the plop will people

know this is set in Middle-earth, copyright New 
Line Cinema, without the all-important definite

article? &quot;A Lord of the Rings? What is this, a 
documentary about a hereditary peer who dabbles

in onion farming?&quot; This is the kind of shit 
you have to expect when you&#39;re dealing with

an IP on this level of milkability, I suppose; 
no adaptation can go out until it&#39;s gone back

and forth through the fucking rotating knives of 
legal teams, marketing departments, lore experts,

and entire buildings full of executives who have 
to justify salaries directly proportional to

the vastness of their lunch breaks. Anyway, 
this extremely efficient process apparently

recently learned that Stardew Valley is a popular 
game after a short, very efficient nine years,

and someone decided they were gonna get them some 
of that. &quot;Here&#39;s an idea: let&#39;s make a cozy game,

broadly speaking, about what would&#39;ve happened 
if the Hobbits had told Gandalf to stick his

walking stick up his arse and just stayed in the 
Shire to focus on gardening and smoking weed.&quot;

So, we play a custom-designed random hobbit; 
we can type in our own first name but have to

pick a surname from a list, so there&#39;s limited 
potential for calling yourself something rude,

but I did my best with &quot;Rampant Chubb.&quot; Rampant 
moves to a small, up-and-coming Hobbit village,

hitching a ride with Gandalf making a token 
appearance (canonically, he spends a lot of

time around hobbits because they sell him weed), 
then we move into someone&#39;s abandoned hobbit hole

we&#39;re entitled to for unclear reasons and set to 
work befriending the neighbors. And it&#39;s all so

bloody twee. Where the The Lord of the Rings (TM) 
movies made themselves popular through brooding,

fantastical adventures and watching hobbits 
getting the absolute taters kicked out of

them for nine hours, here, the main threat 
dealt with by the plot is whether or not the

village you&#39;re in gets officially declared 
a village as opposed to a suburb of a larger

hobbit community. It being very important to 
the locals that they distinguish themselves

from those elitist, latte-drinking, 
white-collar hobbits in the big city.

Does the Shire have a federal government that 
decides what is and is not a village? It always

struck me as one of those hypothetical 
libertarian utopia kind of places that,

in reality, always end up getting taken over by 
the bears no one can be arsed to deal with. Oh,

god. I just got a sense the fucking Middle-earth 
lore experts are mounting on the horizon; let&#39;s

move on. I knew this was shooting for &quot;cozy game,&quot; 
so I wasn&#39;t expecting knife fights, but still,

in the original text, Tolkien doesn&#39;t shy away 
from establishing that hobbits can be nasty,

spiteful little bastards. I mean, there were those 
dudes who kept nicking Bilbo&#39;s furniture. So,

there&#39;s something a little off-brand about the 
utter toothlessness of this game. It&#39;s like the

fucking Gummi Bears cartoon. Closest thing to a 
villainous threat is that the one guy who sells

you flour is a bit of a prick. And that just means 
he&#39;s a little more begrudging in his praise when

you invite him over for tea and pies. Tea and pies 
is more or less the core mechanic of Tales of the

Shire: A The Also Lord of the Rings Copyright 
Tolkien Estate Re: Re: Fw: Fw: Game. You farm,

you forage, you fish, you furtively fail to 
fuck your fellow furry-footed Facebook friends,

but all of it is done in service to the 
time-honored ritual of tea and pies.

There&#39;s about 12 NPCs with actual names; the 
rest are random nobody hobbits that I assume

are all hanging around, waiting for someone 
else to die and free up a house. At any time,

you can invite some of the named neighbors to a 
meal at a specific venue, and doing so is the only

way to build friendship, and building friendships 
is the only way to progress. The meals you have

to cook with the food you&#39;ve farmed, foraged, 
fished, and fermented. So, you can see how tea

and pies hangs over all of the gameplay loops like 
a big, hungry kite. But if this is supposed to get

us attached to the various hobbit NPCs, it cocks 
that right up a prancing pony. I don&#39;t know if you

can romance them (I never got anyone&#39;s friendship 
level high enough to check), but everyone looks

like fuckin&#39; toddlers, so even though Samwise 
Gamgee&#39;s future wife is here, the thought of

enacting my lifelong cuck fantasy just gave me the 
ick. I mainly can&#39;t get attached because firstly,

you&#39;ve got to invite all of them regularly or they 
start getting stroppy, and when you do, they go,

&quot;Sure, I&#39;ll come! Please cook the following 
for me.&quot; You entitled little bitch. You eat

what you&#39;re given; that&#39;s how dinner parties work. 
Do I look like a fucking food truck? Don&#39;t answer

that. And then no one speaks during the party, 
and all have the exact same eating animations.

And when they bugger off, they&#39;re supposed to 
give you a present if your friendship leveled up,

but they don&#39;t do it automatically; you&#39;ve 
gotta sprint after them as they toddle their

way home and go, &quot;Excuse me, I think 
you forgot something; cough, cough;

hold out hand,&quot; like an ill-mannered valet. 
I have many little annoyances—it&#39;s a pain in

the arse having to track down every questgiver in 
person to resolve every single fucking &quot;grow three

potatoes&quot; mini-quest we&#39;re obliged to do to level 
up the &quot;activity clubs,&quot; and incidentally, saying

&quot;joining an activity club&quot; instead of &quot;enslaved 
to a work detail&quot; is a useful tip for anyone

planning to start their own libertarian cult. 
I wish there was a drop box at my home I could

use to sell things instead of having to run to 
a merchant who might&#39;ve gone home for the night,

much as that might&#39;ve scuppered your case whence 
cometh the Stardew Valley copyright lawsuit. These

are nitpicks, perhaps, but in a repetitive, cozy, 
zone-out game, the little nitpicks mount up. They

become the metaphorical pee under a mattress 
that means the princess can&#39;t sleep at night,

but then maybe she shouldn&#39;t have 
drunk so much before bed, mnehehehe.

Pros: this is probably the most involved cooking 
minigame I&#39;ve ever seen, just as well considering

its importance, and I kinda like how you&#39;re guided 
to your destination by birds landing on signs;

nice immersive navigation system. Although 
training entire flocks of wild birds to

intuit my intended destination seems like a weird 
hassle to put yourself through when you forgot to

give me a fucking compass. What condemns 
Tales of the Shite: An I&#39;m Bored of This

Shite Game is that it conflates coziness with 
laziness. At the thrilling story moment of our

village being declared a village (slow the fuck 
down, Michael Bay), the NPCs are all like, &quot;Ah,

remember when you first came here, Rampant Chubb? 
What an adventure we&#39;ve had since then.&quot; &quot;Er,

yeah, it was three weeks ago; we haven&#39;t 
even gotten to winter yet. Why are you

talking like this is the end of the stor-oh. 
Oh, that didn&#39;t take long.&quot; &quot;Don&#39;t worry,

you can still level up relationships and 
activity clubs for as long you want.&quot; Yeah,

thanks, asshole. Maybe there&#39;s more story 
later; frankly, I only played long enough

after that to see what winter is like and was 
disappointed one last time to find that all

they do is recolor the vegetation white. &quot;Wow, 
look at the white leaves on all the trees, those

things that famously have leaves during winter.&quot; 
Yeah, can&#39;t recommend, frankly. More like &quot;Lord

of the I&#39;d Rather Be Doing Other Things.&quot; Sorry, 
I meant to say, &quot;THE Lord of the I&#39;d Rather Be-&quot;
